thread.title: Delaware crashing Philly's first Cheesesteak Festival
thread.title_full: Delaware crashing Philly's first Cheesesteak Festival

title: Delaware crashing Philly's first Cheesesteak Festival
text:
Delaware crashing Philly's first Cheesesteak Festival Ryan Cormier , The News Journal 2:43 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 The first Philadelphia Cheesesteak Festival is at Lincoln Financial Field Saturday. (Photo: iStockphoto) 104 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
When Newark’s Leigh Ann Tona rolls up to Lincoln Financial Field for Philadelphia’s first Cheesesteak Festival Saturday, she will be cooking alongside Philly cheesesteak kings like Geno’s and Pat’s on their home turf. 
And if you think that might be a little intimidating for the owner of the I Don’t Give a Fork food truck, you’re right. 
“That was my big concern when I first heard about it: I’m going to Philly with a Delaware food truck and they are going to laugh me right out of Lincoln Financial Field. There’s no way this is going to work,” she says. “But then I saw they were up to 40 food vendors and I thought if there are 40, I can’t be the worst one there. I figured I’d give it a shot.” 
Even though Tona may be a little nervous, one of the festival organizers, David Feldman Jr., chief operating officer of Delaware County, Pa.-based Elite Events Management Group, says Tona should have no fear. Buy Photo 
Newark-based I Don't Give a Fork food truck and its owner Leigh Ann Tona will be one of two Delaware vendors at the first Philadelphia Cheesesteak Festival this weekend. (Photo: News Journal file) 
She has a secret weapon: her signature Mac & Cheesesteak. You guessed it. It’s a cheesesteak with grilled onions and creamy macaroni and cheese mixed in. 
“I think she’s going to kill it. I think it’s going to be a major attraction,” Feldman says, adding that the fest will not only have traditional cheesesteaks, but also cheesesteak dumplings, cheesesteak egg rolls, cheesesteak tacos and more. 
The final number of vendors has reached 60 for the festival , which just sold out its 25,000 tickets, Feldman says. He says it will be back as an annual event. 
In addition to the sandwiches, there will be a cheesesteak eating competition, "the world's largest cheesesteak," a zip line, a mechanical bull, cornhole and carnival games. Late night TV reacts: Biden is 'Jay Z of Delaware' 
Unfortunately for Tona, the festival will be held outside of the stadium at the 10,000-square-foot HeadHouse Plaza and the nearby K parking lot, so she won’t be able roll across Philadelphia Eagles’ home field in her truck. 
In addition to the Newark-based I Don’t Give a Fork food truck, Middletown’s Out of the Ordinary Catering is the only other First State representative at the festival, which also count’s Bear-based marketer Kevin Baxter as an organizer and the man behind the initial idea. 
Even Vice President Joe Biden likes cheesesteaks. In 2010, he stopped at Pat's King of Steaks in Philadelphia for a bite. (Photo: Matt Rourke/AP) 
Another bit of Delaware flavor at the festival will come from one of the day’s entertainers, cover band Go Go Gadjet, which has been dominating the summer scene in Dewey Beach for the last few years. 
Robert Yalley, owner of the 11-year-old Out of the Ordinary Catering, heard about the festival through friends – friends that are traveling from states like New York, Virginia and Baltimore just to gorge on the belly-busting buffet, which costs between $20-$60 to attend. 
“They are coming from everywhere,” says Yalley, who counts Pat’s King of Steaks as his favorite. 
Geno's Steaks will participate in this weekend's inaugural Philadelphia Cheesesteak Festival. (Photo: Getty Images) 
As for Tona, she says she’s been encouraged by the number of Delawareans that bought tickets for the festival, hoping for some hometown love while in the big city. 
And if she happens to get a thumbs up from a Philadelphian who normally chows down on cheesesteaks from Philly favorites like Pat’s, Geno’s, Jim’s or Tony Luke’s, it will have been worth it: “I would be so pumped!” IF YOU GO 
When: Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 
Where: Lincoln Financial Field, 1 Lincoln Financial Field Way, Philadelphia 
Tickets: Sold out 
Information: cheesesteakfest.com 
Contact Ryan Cormier of The News Journal at rcormier@delawareonline.com or (302) 324-2863. Follow him on Facebook ( @ryancormier ), Twitter ( @ryancormier ) and Instagram ( @ryancormier ). 104 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://delonline.us/1LPicFj MORE STORIES
